page.title: 01TWEEN HADLOW AND DUNKS GREEN
page.content: Traversing this rural area via winding, narrow, hedged and somwrimes deep lanes or well-used footpaths one is struck by an everchanging landscape, open rolling fields, woods, copses, orchards. houses, small holdings and numerous ponds and lakes. Predominantly arable land produces crops for human and animal consumption. Cultivated and rough grassland supports sheep and some cattle. Large area of woodland lies to the south west, both coniferous and deciduous with bluebells. Between the village of Hadlow (in the south east) and the snall hamlet of Dunks Green (in the north west) are scattered old farmhouses, oathouses, cottages and larger country houses with open parkland. The land rises in an arc from south west to north east where lies Gover Hill (13/m) with extensive
